It's current yet another way to limit whether 'embeds' are crawled. I
agree this is a bad place to get that effect, and DONT_SCHEDULE an
awkward overloading of the 'schedulingDirective' value. See my
comments at:

  http://sourceforge.net/tracker/index.php?func=detail&aid=1180683&group_id=73833&atid=539102

Scopes based on chains of DecidingRules can probably meet this need
best: a late rule that REJECTs any URI whose last hop-type is an embed
would mostly do the job. (The fact that some 'E'mbeds are frame HTML
contents could still be an issue; we may need a new 'F' hop-type.)

- Gordon

Kristinn Sigurdsson wrote:
> "If enabled, embeded links (images etc.) are tested against scope"
>  
> Reading that I figured that this means that if disabled then embedded links
> will be scheduled unconditionally (although if recheck of scope is enabled
> in the Preselecter they may be discarded there!)
>  
> However, when I reviewed the code I discovered that, yes, if 'true' then
> embedded links are treated normally, but if 'false' embedded links all have
> the scheduling directive set to DONT_SCHEDULE which I take to mean that it
> will never be crawled. However, I can find no evidence that the directive is
> supported by the Frontiers which may lead to some interesting side effects
> since the value of the directive is -1 and generally a lower directive value
> is assumed to mean higher priority. I would suggest that the boys at the
> Archive take a second, much closer, look at this.
>  
> I would further suggest that if we wish to mark URIs as 'unschedulable',
> this not be done via the scheduling directive, or at the very least uses a
> value that is higher then NORMAL since most calculations about scheduling
> directives involves simple greater then or less then comparisons of the
> integers! (In fact preconditions are (were?) assigned their parent's
> scheduling directive minus one.) Perhaps the entire scheduling directive
> needs a closer look.
>  
> I would also suggest that there is generally no need for unconditionally
> passing embedded URIs through the scope (if that was ever the intention)
> since that only muddies up where the scope determination is performed.
>  
> - Kris
>
